pullRequest.body:
Generalize some existing lemmas from `CompleteLinearOrder`s to `ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrder`s, adding the appropriate boundedness assumptions:

- `Monotone.map_limsSup_of_continuousAt` + its 3 order-dual variants
- `Monotone.map_limsup_of_continuousAt` + its 3 order-dual variants
- `Monotone.map_sSup_of_continuousAt'` + its 3 order-dual variants
- `Monotone.map_iSup_of_continuousAt'` + its 3 order-dual variants

For the first two to work automatically still on `CompleteLinearOrder`s, the existing macro tactic `isBoundedDefault` about boundedness of filters is used. For the last two to work automatically still on `CompleteLinearOrder`s, a similar new macro tactic `bddDefault` about boundedness of sets is included in the PR.





---

  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/5797820527/job/15714207564)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/5797820527/job/15714206954)
Final nitpicks!
Final nitpicks!

I think you can use something like `(h : f.IsBoundedUnder (Â· â‰¤ Â·) u := by isBoundedDefault)`. See [tendsto_of_liminf_eq_limsup](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Order/LiminfLimsup.html#tendsto_of_liminf_eq_limsup) for example.
If it works indeed you should replace the existing versions.

Thank you! This seems to work. I'm renaming the new ones to see if they now work throughout Mathlib as direct replacements of the old ones. (I currently only did this for 4 lemmas, but I will do the same for the other 4 if Mathlib compiles, and in fact also for yet another 4 which were just alternative phrasings.)

If I get to removing the old ones altogether, is it ok to keep the `#align`s although the type signature will have changed? Since the results would presumably still work with the same _explicit_ arguments, my naive opinion is that aligning would still be ok.
Yes that's fine, because 1) indeed this is close enough in practice and 2) we got past `port-complete` so we don't need to be as careful as before IIUC.
The tactic `isBoundedDefault` was for filters only (as far as I understood). I wrote a similar 2-line macro `setIsBddDefault` to be used with default boundedness of sets.

Oh, or would it be desirable that the same tactic handles automatic boundedness of both filters and sets in complete linear orders? The tactic `isBoundedDefault` seemed to be in `Filter` namespace, so I thought boundedness of sets would not be in scope, but now I'm not so sure anymore...

Yes I think the best solution is to have the same tactic taking care of both. That said, I've thought about it a few times before, and arrived to the conclusion that there is a "good" reason that we don't have the set version: even if we had, we wouldn't be able to merge the APIs of `CompleteLattice` and `ConditionallyCompleteLattice`, because we still can't get rid of the `Nonempty` assumptions that are required in the conditionally complete case but not in the complete case. This situation doesn't happen for (nontrivial?) filters, so here it makes more sense to have each lemma once.

That doesn't mean that we shouldn't add it, in fact it can't hurt and I have some ideas about a (gigantic) refactor that would make it useful, I just wanted to mention why it's not so strange that it is missing.

On the technical side, I'm not sure how to make it so that the same tactic work without messing up with the import tree. We could probably take inspiration about `positivity` that is split into small extensions, but if that gets too hard then having two tactics is not that bad (you basically never have to call these tactics explicitly anyway)
I think having two tactics is fine for now. If this kind of thing keeps coming up we can develop a uniform way to deal with it.
I have some ideas about how to make these a bit stronger, but it would be a bit long to explain. Is it fine if I just open a PR so you can look at it?

Actually explaining the math idea is not long: the underlying result is really that, if `F.IsBoundedUnder (Â· â‰¤ Â·) u)` and `u` is monotone, then `F.IsBoundedUnder (Â· â‰¤ Â·) (f âˆ˜ u)`, which implies your result. The thing that would be long to explain is how I suggest setting up the API :sweat_smile:

That would be great, of course! Thanks! (For me these were just a way to get unstuck in the proofs of the lemmas mentioned in the PR description, which in turn were mainly a way to get unstuck elsewhere...)

I've opened that PR as #6287. For example, if `hf : Monotone f` and `bdd : F.IsBoundedUnder (Â· â‰¤ Â·) u` you have `(hf.isBoundedUnder_le bdd).isCoboundedUnder_ge : F.IsCoboundedUnder (Â· â‰¥ Â·) (f âˆ˜ u)`. If that is too long you can keep the `Cobounded` version too of course, and prove it that way.

```suggestion
    f (sSup A) = sSup (f '' A) :=
  --This is a particular case of the more general `IsLUB.isLUB_of_tendsto`
  .symm <| ((isLUB_csSup A_nonemp A_bdd).isLUB_of_tendsto (Mf.monotoneOn _) A_nonemp <| 
    Cf.mono_left inf_le_left).csSup_eq (A_nonemp.image f)
```
I think this is a bit nicer, but tbh I'm not sure

```suggestion
  Monotone.map_sSup_of_continuousAt' (Î± := Î±áµ’áµˆ) (Î² := Î²áµ’áµˆ) Cf Mf.dual A_nonemp A_bdd
```
Let's use our new fancy features!
Same below

> Let's use our new fancy features! Same below

There were a lot of `@ _ _ _ _ _` for order dual applications in these files. It turned out easier to search and replace all of them. Unfortunately that increases the diff, this could have been a separate chore PR...

I hope this type of a change is first of all a readability improvement, and second of all more robust. For robustness, instead of the exact number of arguments and order of arguments in the lemmas, with named arguments we now rely on the names of a couple of arguments (although unfortunately those names are often alphas and betas and gammas). So code could break if argument names are changed elsewhere in the library, but I think fixing is then easy enough.

```suggestion
      apply liminf_le_of_frequently_le _ (bdd_above.isBoundedUnder f_decr)
      exact (B.mono fun x hx â†¦ f_decr hx)
```

```suggestion
    push_neg at h'
```

What do you think of keeping the structure of the existing proof treating the case where `F.limsSup` is a bottom element (using [IsBot](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Max.html#IsBot)) separately from the beginning?

Sorry, I honestly can't form an opinion about that!

I guess I mainly opted for not talking about a bottom element, since under the conditionally complete hypotheses it is not given that a bottom element exists. But the proof ends up being a bit of a case bash anyway, and one way to handle some cases would be to consider the case that there indeed exists a bottom element and `F.limsSup` happens to be that.

Is it the number of (nested) reasoning steps that argue by contradiction that seems questionable style here?

I really don't know what would be elegant (or the least inelegant) here. Do you have a clear opinion?

Thinking about it again I think your structure is actually good (and there was no style issue at all with that, I was mostly nit-picking). The only thing I'd change about the structure is I think it would be clearer if you did 
```lean
have : \not IsBot F.limsSup := by sorry
```
after `by_contra' H` and then use that in the obtain. Is that clear enough?

```suggestion
      apply liminf_le_of_frequently_le _ _
```

I think it would be better to call it `bddDefault` (to match `BddAbove`/`BddBelow`) in namespace `Set` and move in just after [OrderBot.bddBelow](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Bounds/Basic.html#OrderBot.bddBelow)

I could not get the namespace for the macro working by enclosing in a namespace or by directly preceding the name with `Set.`.

I moved the macro as suggested, and renamed it `setBddDefault` for now.
Ah right, this doesn't work like in Lean3. I'd say just `bddDefault` should be fine.

```suggestion
      exists_lt_of_lt_csSup (bdd_above.recOn fun x hx â†¦ âŸ¨f x, Set.mem_image_of_mem f hxâŸ©) hc
```
Your version breaks the set/predicate border, which is bad for readability of the tactic state

```suggestion
    have not_bot : Â¬ IsBot F.limsSup := fun maybe_bot â†¦
      lt_irrefl (F.liminf f) <| lt_of_le_of_lt
```

```suggestion
      simpa [IsBot] using not_bot
```
